Tigard, Oregon
November 8th 1960
Fellow Worker Thompson!
In regards to Wobbly Folklore, I could perhaps be of some help to You in regards to the song Tie em Up,, now I have sung the song many times in words and music for and to myself and I know the tune and words of the first and part of the second verse, but I am unable to write music and tune in notes, so there is where we neat assistance, I will write the words of the first verse, as I recall it and the refrain and if we get the first verse and refrain in to music all the other verses and refrain are the same tune. I will write the words down, to the best of my memory, and You see if you can correct me, if not, we will stick to my words, then I will try to get a party, that can write music and notes and does play Piano! as I live about 10 (over)

miles from Portland Oregon, it would have to be sombody in this Neighborhood, it could are a Finnisch Person, that can write music and You could give my Name and Address in the Industrial Worker, as I am reading it, I am 68 years old and retired and not a card carrying member, I have joined the Wobblies in 1912 in Minneapolis and was active up to 1950, the last time I heard the Tie em up song sung by a fellow Worker around Christmastime in 1917 in the Wobbly Hall in San Francisco and my melody might be a little out of tune, but that could be adjusted. I have also have heard Joe Hills Workers of the World awaken in 2 different tunes.  
Yours for the O. B. U. 
Alfred Näfken
No. 10855. S. W. Walnut Street
Tigard. Oregon

P.S.
if You have not all the verses, that ago with the song Tie em up, I have another possible chance to trace them. In 1928-1929, I made a trip to my home in Hamburg, Germany and toke 6 Wobbly Song Books along, they where then at that time the latest edition and they most likely had the complete song and possible gave the tune also, but as far as I can remember, it has none of the tune and melody of any other song I know of,  It is in a class by itself! I stayed 11 months in Germany, and had 2 Boys, who wanted to learn "English" and what better Book could I use than "the Wobbly Song" book, its the tune and the words that sure took them, well I gave each one of the Boys a Wobbly Song Book and kept one for myself as a text book, now this all was way before Hitler toke over, and in the meantime Hamburg was 2/3 destroyed, but as chance would have it my house kept standing, despite the fact that everything for 7 Block square was destroyed
over

when I left Germany in the spring of 1929, I Ieft a lot of books and Literatur behind and it is possible, that a old Wobbly Song book is amongst that. I also found out that one of the Boys I gave a song book at that time survived the war and may still have it. may I suggest, that we ship as many Wobbly Song books by Sailors, to the new-created Countries in Africa, mainly to English speaking and former English Colonies as our Wobbly Songs are having the most effect on people who understand and speak english, Now Joe Hills and all the others Wobbly Songs, if translated in to other Languages, even Scandinavian ore German, are not so convincing as those written in English, besides in all other languages, the Communist and other Politicians have an awfull gripp on the Working Class and Labor Unions.
Alfred Näfken
No 10855. S.W. Walnut Street
Tigard. Oregon

Here is the song "Tie em up" as I remember it. 
We have no fight with Brothers of the Great A.F. of L
the only things we ask You have some Reason now to tell
Your craft is but protection for a form of property
the skill that You are loosing, dont you see 
improvements on Maschinery, take Your tool and skill away
and You'll be on the Rocks some fatefull Day! 
The Day when You begin to see the Classes waging war 
You can join the biggest [?Ti Up?] that You ever saw before. 
Refrain 
Tie em up, Tie em up, thats the way to winn
dont notify the Bosses, let Hostilitys beginn
dont furnish chance for [?Gunnmenn?] Scabs and their alike
what You want is one big Union and the one Big Strike. 
Why do You make agreements that devide You when You fight 
and let the Bosses bluff You with the Contract sacred right. 
that all I remember. 
Alfred Näfken
No. 10855. SW. Walnut Street. Tigard, Oregon

(1)
Anna Smith   P.O. Box 552,  Oakland   Ca. 94604
Fred Thompson  Chicago, Ill. 
Dear F. W., 
Just a few lines - I've owed you more than a few lines for quite a while. 
Misplaced your letter.   First I read of the loss of your help-mate. I won't extend my sympathy - but say I'm happy she has escaped from latter days of suffering. For you I'm sure you have many happy memories of your life to-gether. 
As to the visit to F.W.s  in S. F. I went to see them. A pleasant - and some what fruitful escape. He suggested I go see Melvin  - "that he is a good cook" Seems as tho' I have remembrance of a long distance discussion between you and Melvin some years ago. Haven't gotten in touch with the two since nor they with me. 

  As to your question I believe it was - Vincent St. John - no, I didn't know him - I've heard of him and read some. 
  I don't know any German - studied a little French and Spanish at night school. I should have kept it up.
  Hope to buy your First 75 yrs of the I.W.W. one of these days. 
  My days with I.W.W. only reaches back to 1937.   1929 or 1930 & 31, 32 I took part in the Unemployed Movement.

(2)
and several related organizations. 
No time now to go into more detail. 
My Dad in 1914 - took us (my 2 brothers and me) to Socialist party crossed out - tickets picnic - in Santa Ana, Southern California - and he voted for Eugene V. Debs - but he and my mother in 1917 (I think it was) voted for Woodrow Wilson for president - because of his promise to keep America out of war. 

  My mother with her father in Kansas (he and my grand mother home-steaded160 acres & bot [?]  acres more) belonged to the Knights of Labor. [in left margin:] In 1878 - her family came in covered wagon from Iowa  First lived in sod house - burnt buffalo chips water from river at a distance
   I went to see Earl last Sunday. He was sitting on front porch of rest house. He's always seems to be pleased to have visitors. Even in spite of illness - he keeps somewhat the same spirit underneath

-Thats all for now 
Best Wishes
I remain
For O B U.
Anna. 
To Fred Thompson.

University of Illinois ILIR Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations  Telephone 12173 333-1462  304 East Armory Avenue, Champaign, Illinois  61620
May 26, 67
Dear Fred, 
In the last few days I have been going thru the little red songbook as well as a microfilm of the IW for 1909-13. I am tempted to write a book on IWW songs but am obligated to finish my coal thesis. 
Meanwhile I prepared 3 checklists for Gibbs: songs, songbooks, ads and articles. Naturally each list can be refined. But I had to mail the sheets to Gibbs today. The verifax copies are for your use. 
The Swedish material is "frosting" on the cake. 
Cordially, 
Archie
[Printed logo: ]  University of Illinois Centennial Year 1967-68

201 West Pennsylvania
Urbana, Illinois
Jan 21,  61
Dear Fred,
Thank you for your welcome letter, the Wrone carbon, and the Nafken letter. I respond at once. I did plan to come to Chicago and had indicated to Chuck D. that I would. However, I was quite sick -- flu and fever --and actually lost a week of work.

I had a strong reason to come and see you for there is some good news on my Wob lore project.  I'll try to put it in sequence. About a year ago Phil Taft urged me to visit Dick Brazier in N.Y.C. When Joe Glazer put out his recent book he sent a copy to Brazier and they corresponded. Joe suggested that I see Dick. I went East to Philly for an Am Folklore Society meeting Dec 27-29. From Philly I went up to NY and met Brazier at the Taminent Inst (old Rand School). We chose this site so I could show Dick my microfilm of Neuhaus songbooks. It was the first time he had seen some of his own songs since 1917 when the Feds raided his ?gear? . 

We met on Friday and talked. We returned on Saturday when it was quiet and made a 3 hr tape. I tried to concentrate on the early days in Spokane. Also I tried to explore the problem of

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:0

element_texts.text:
2
whether Dick or any of the other Wob minstrels and bards were conscious of the folksong concept (as it is used by contemporary academic folklorists).

On New Yrs Eve Dick took me to an IWW party at the home of Becky Dempsey. I met Herbert Mahler, Pete Stone, and others. Dick had given Pete my Neuhaus article. Pete helped me on the songs.   He had heard "some 400 cats who had come from the midwest to winter up in Seattle" sing "The Kitten in the Wheat" in 1916. You'll recall that that John Neuhaus had given his source for the "Kitten" as the Literary Digest. It could have been planted against the IWW as a phony. But Pete Stone was quite certain it had been sung and even sang a stanza for me. Naturally I was elated because it was my first evidence that the "Kitten" was actually sung.  

Meanwhile Brazier calmly informed me that "The Kitten" is a direct parody of a well known Cornish poem and song by Robert Stephen Hawker who was also known as "The Vicar of Morwenstow."  The poem is called "The Song of the Western Men" or the "Trelawny Ballad" since it

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:0

element_texts.text:
3
is built round the refrain: And shall Trewlawney  Die? Then 30 000 Cornish boys will know the reason why!
It had been a folk refrain. Hawker turned it into a poem in 1826. It reentered oral tradition. Cousinjack miners sang it: Then 30,000 underground will know the reason why!
At any rate someone who knew the "Trewlawney Ballad" or song, as literature or folksong composed the "Kitten" parody. More on this problem later.
I do not want to bore you with all the details.  But to make a long story short I learned very much from Dick and Pete and plan to correspond with both.
I returned from NY via Akron. There I learned that Joe Glazer had been in Portland at a printing-newspaper strike rally and had had Ralph Chaplin come down from Tacoma to address the rally. Joe got Ralph's talk on tape. If all goes well I'll go to SF on June 5-8 for a library convention. Since I'll have some vacation time coming I'll return to Illinois via Tacoma.  My plan

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:0

element_texts.text:
4
is to visit Chaplin. What is jelling in my mind, Fred, is the necessity to finish Neuhaus' projected book. I have talked to my director, Martin Wagner, who is sympathetic to labor history. I have told him that as soon as I get the library job under control I'll want time off to write a book. So we'll see what happens.
You can see, Fred, why I became sick. I'm running a fair sized library, have two assistants on separate bibliographies, help students like David Wrone and Marion Ascareli, and try to pursue my own studies.  It was in NY that I picked up the flu bug that laid me low.
Just a word on Wrone. He has already learned that Carl Person is alive in Chi and a meeting is arranged. My interest here it to push history students into labor history. A fault in our industrial relations approach is too much technology and not enuf perspective.
I have raced thru this letter like a house-a-fire. I'll be in Chicago Feb 3-5 with  Louanne for a folk festival at U of Chi. I'll bring her up to visit.
Archie

Oxford Mich.
in type (file Detroit
in pen F. W. Thompson
I recieved your letter concerning a certain Philip Krik in relation to Wobbly history in Detroit.
I don't even know if there is substantial I.W.W. history in Detroit.
To my knowledge the only wobbly participation to any significance was the Briggs strike here. The only F.W one that I kew [sic] of that was active in that strike was F. W. Frank Cicarelli who has been dead many years.
The only people here who could (possibly) help Krik in any way, you already know of, i.e. Verlain and Lucas both branch secretaries and delegates at one time.
Then, there are the Wayne State archives, which I should think would cover all known wobbly history, here.   I was able to contact Harry Riseman and had an interesting talk.
I was unaware that he was the lawyer who was instrumental in stopping your deportation, altho we din't [?brook?] on that subject.
He, of course immediately recognized your name, in response to my question, does the name of Fred Thompson jar in your memory?

7/8/87
Dear Fellow Worker,
This is in response to Florence Tromater and Jenny Velsek's notice that you are collecting biographical material on Fred Thompson. I am enclosing copies of his correspondence with me - mostly from him to me but a few from myself or my wife to him.
I have put them in chronological order (latest on top) to the best of my ability. Those that are not dated, I have placed according to my best guess as to the time they belong to.
I hope this is useful. Please let me know if you have any questions.
Yours for OBU,
Ed John

element_texts.text:
Vahns -
Roth says you may settle here. I would like that. Intended to enclose clipping but mislaid it - re British device of a new programming  language 'Pop II' said to be usable by highschool kids with 4 hrs training.  My S. [?] pal Pete Meyers says he expects to remain addicted to Fortran.

  Your Input-Output tables & references to Math aroused pleasant recollections of when we used to discuss circulation of capital in simple reproduction & expansion - and my shooting some Marxists with a simplistic popularization of same - an insulated economy, capitalistic, with only two towns, one at either end of the island - Breadtown turning out on a means of consumption, and Steeltown at other end producing only means of production, with inevitable movement of goods between the two towns restriated (discarding c+v+s distinctions temporarily) to a swopping of the part of Breadtown's product that corresponds to replacement of means and expansion of means, for the portion of Steeltown's production that corresponds to all consumed income, all classes.
  For my "New Unionism" series, I'd like an easy, even if superficial explanation that modern equipment as computers, do make it not too difficult for workers to world over to approximate optimum use of resources toward achieving their wishes regarding levels of consumption (Perhaps we should concede the computers can't assure us that the wishes will be rational?)

Yours   Fred
[in left margin]  --See other side --

29 Palm, Calif.
Aug. 25, 1968
Dear F.W.T.
More than a month since you mailed that letter dealing with the little red song book so I am late with my response for cause. Been jungling up in the High Sierras for two months during which time I only connected twice with my first class mail and that because of the checks.  Would have stayed away longer but cold wheather chased us southward before the expected time. Ice in the water bucket settled the matter as to stay or not to stay.
I am happy to hear that meaningful improvement will be made in the forthcomming editions of the little red song book. Its about time too, let me tell you.
At this time I have another letter from Dick Brazier saying he was mistaken about being left out in the last printing of the song book. A New York friend of his had told him so in error. Since then he has been supplied with a copy and was happy to find his song in it. All

I sort of liked the little history sketch that D.B. wrote on the little red song book and which Philip Taft saw fit to pick up for Labor History. I don't know if D.B. shares my criticism of the contents of the song book. He has not said yet, except to agree with me, that the old English socialist songs are hard to improve on. Songs by F. A. Symonds for example. "These things shall be! A loftier race/Than e'er the world hath known shall rise/With flame of freedom in their souls/And light of knowledge in their eyes." Songs by Morris, Blake, James Russel Lowel, Carpenter, Cooper, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Joseph Whittaker etc etc.  The inclusion of these authors, or part of them, in your forthcoming editions would still make it a little red  song book though not a little red IWW song book exclusively. As I said in my letter to H. M. E. Seattle much

crap could be cut out from the present editions to make room for something better. Even some new songs by American rebell groups could easely qualify for your proposed new improved edition. The correction in the Red Flag is appreciated I mean the line which now reads  -- "Chicago swells its surging "song" should read "surging throng" instead. The fourth verse as rendered in the IWW song book is intirely different in my English I.L.P. song book. There it reads "It well recalls the triumphs past/ It gives the hope of peace at last/ The banner bright, the symbol plain/ Of human right and human gain." There has been a great deal of doctoring up of socialist songs in the past not all of it improving on the authors. Eugene Pottier would not be able to recognise his L'Internationale were he alife today. This brings me to the point that Joe Hills line "the ends the means are justifying" could also be doctored up to conform more closely to our hearts desire. Well, best of luck to (over)

[seal of the organization]

6-16-64

F. W. Rosemont
There is a motion before the board at this time, which I am sure will pass. Notable - That the GEB Chairman shall countersign all checks issued at Headquarters with a provision that when Chairman does  not reside in Chicago that the GEB Chairman shall delegate someone there for a period not longer than one year.

  Could you be my delegate in this capacity.  It would require that you first, countersign all checks - two, keep a simple record of to whom a how much each check is & supply a monthly report of same to Chairman prior to the publishing of the GOB.
  Give me an answer by return mail.  I'll have to have a delegate on hand as soon as this motions

F.W. Rosemont - If the IWW is growing to day, it is because an active young and vigorous Generation is taking it over. For Many Long years the old Time Members have done nothing but pay the Landlords the Rent; Sit around the Halls and play cards for a Pass Time and Philosophy all Day.
The IWW Members and Friends Should hold their heads high and be Proud that it is on the Subversive List of the Master Class which it always has been Since it was first organized in Chicago Ills in 1905.
More active IWW Members are needed over in Yakima Wash this Summer and Fall, I think the Members over there will open a Hall in the Near Future. It will no doubt be a hard fight over there if the Drive Proves Successful.
Its too bad the IWW Members sold the Mimeograph and type writer here as The Wobs over in Yakima Wash could Sure make use of Them Now. The Leading Light in the Seattle Branch was hard as Hell to co-operate with

Yakima is on the Main Line of the Northern Pacific RR and a Branch Line of the Union Pacific RR. Sure wish I was able to make Yakima Wash and help out in the IWW Drive in Yakima Valley this Summer and Fall.
  Yours for a fighting IWW
  Gary B. Askew (Skidroad Slim)

Personal
J.W Rosemont.  The IWW Members and Friends out here dont give a Damn whether it ever gets off the Subversive List or not, they intend to carry on The Struggle for it any way.  From its very begainning They Know only too well the IWW has always been on The Shit List of The Master Class and its armed State and Government.  For years there has been a few old Marxian Centralizers  who have wanted to Make the IWW Respectable in the Eyes of the capitalist class.  These characters have Set around doing nothing to Build it up worrying only about getting it off The Subversive List for years.  I hope the young Libertarian IWW's take it over eventually.
yours for a Militant youth full IWW Member Ship
Guy B Askew (Skidroad Slim)
Keep up the Good Work for The IWW

The history of its 1000 mile picket line and Many Strikes as well as its Many free Speech fights in the harvest Fields Should be [?] also, especially one Like the Minot North Dakota free Speech fight of 1916 When hundreds of IWW members filled the Jails and Stockade in  that city; and won all Their Demands; to open a Hall, hold Mass Meetings on the Streets as well as have IWW News Boys on the Streets and else where.  They had to fight the Minot City Bulls, County Sheriffs and City Fire Dept and beat them all to a [?];  Damn near Broke the city of

Their Halls was Kept clean at all Times Literature fully displayed in The Window  a young Man Was selling Solidarity, The Industrial Worker, WWW Song Books and Literature on The Streets.  There was a sign on The Wall Regarding "No Drunks" allowed and it was Strictly enforced.

This Letter Not for Publication
F. W. Rosemont - The Seattle Skidroad has been well covered with IWW Red Black Cat Stickers and Leaflets, as has Yakima Valley.

 Well The IWW has always been on the Subversive list of The Capitalist Class because of its Workers Revolutionary Preamble.  Its Sincere and active Members I am Sure are Proud of it, and they dont waste time Trying to get it off that honorable List
 Here in Wash State The Legislative abolished The Criminal Syndicalist Law, but The Criminal anarchist Law Remains on The Law Book, but is never used.  you can cartoon The Black Cat and wooden Shoe in The Rebel Worker, with out comment, So as not to offend The Royal GEB of the IWW.  Well The Capitalist Class Starts a war. Kills part of The Workers, So they can make huge profits, and The other part of The Wage Slaves Can Remain at Home and have Jobs.
 The1917 IWW Song Book carried Labor Songs Some Written By F.W. Joe Hill Who Wrote a Booklet advocating it.  The IWW Was full of fighting Spirit and growing to beat Hell as a Result of it.

The IWW Now has a Good Toe hold in Yakima Valley Wash; but The IWW Members over there need help, Such as mony [sic] and foot Lose active wobs to Come to Yakima and give Them a hand.  IWW Members across the County Should use every means possible to Raise funds for The active Wobs in Yakima, Such as Dances entertainments, Mass Meeting and Individual Donations Send directly to F. W. Dear F.W,S - The Rail Road freight trains now average 55 miles an hour, The RR Divisions are much Longer than they use to be and The Red Ball [?Line?] freights Lay over only a very Short Time at a Division Point.  Riding in a Modern hydra coushion car is as easy and comfortable as Riding in a Passenger Coach or first Class Pullman car.
From Chicago to St. Paul Minneapolis Minn there are two Very Friendly Roads to Ride The Burlington RP and The Milwaukee RR.  From there on to Yakima and The beautiful Pacific North West including Seattle you have The Great Northern RR, The Northern Pacific RR to Yakima Wash and The Milwaukee RR all Damn Good Friendly Roads to The Migratory Wage Slaves;  The hoboes, Tramps or any one else Who Wishes to accept their Box Car and Jungle Hospitality

 Now The freight Trains Still Remain one of the fastest and Best Ways to Spread IWW Propaganda to the Wage Slaves Coast to Coast in The USA.

Very active IWW Speakers, Job Delegates, News Boys Literature Sellers and Leaflet Distributors Singers and Even Musicians if possible Will be Needed.  All Members Must be urged to Keep Neat and Clean in appearance at all Times.  Educate organize Sober up and wake up the Tame apes.
Warmest Greetings to you young wobs -
Yours for an active Libertarian IWW.
Guy B. Askew (Skidroad Slim) Room 25  Fremont Hotel  707 -6th ave. So  Seattle Wash 98104
Feb 20, 1965
The wage Slaves cant fight The Boss and the Booze at The Same Time

ACADEMIE DE MONTPELLIER
COLLEGE LES GARRIGUES
145, avenue du Comte-de-Nice
LA PAILLADE 34100 MONTPELLIER
Telephone 75.20.56
Montpellier, le February 17, 1955
Dear Sir,
I am working on a book "The Winning of the War as seen through the Songs of The Time, 1840-1910", And I would like to obtain a xerox of the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, & 4th editions of the IWW's Little Red Songbook "Songs of The Workers - to Fan the Flames of Discontent" published in 1909, 1910, 1912 in Spokane, WA. Could you please suggest possible sources from which I could get photocopies. They have only the 1928 edition in the Library of Congress and and I doubt they store such material in Spokane Public Library, the town being such a conservative place (I know it by experience, I spent two years there)
I read in "Sing Out - the Folksong Magazine" that the 35th edition of the Little Red Song Book was issued Last May - Could you please send me a copy. I have enclosed a check for $3, which should cover the postage by surface mail. (I have already the 34th edition..)
Sincerely, G. Dubois
Guy DUBOIS, Professeur
Fontaine Opaline
134 rue du Curat 
34100 MONTPELLIER

August 23, 1983
Dear Fellow Worker Pfaff,

  Thank you for the letter of August 13 - we appreciate your writing regarding "The IWW Book Fund" for which we share your concern.
   We have been thinking about this matter and have some thoughts you might want to consider.
  As you know Mike Kaciban was a good and true friend and in his memory as well as those fifty oldtime dedicated Wobblies who sacrificed so much - we feel very protective of that fund and would like to see it's principal kept in a money market type fund with interest continuing to roll over and build up as it appears to be doing now.
  In the event that a special program or project should come up we feel the interest could be made available - always being sure that the principal remained intact.  We know how easy it would be fore the full amount to be used up very rapidly leaving nothing and  that is what we would like to avoid.
  One thought is to transfer the fund from Hollywood to Willoughby where perhaps my daughter, Patty and I could join you and Frank as co-signers or any other person you would recommend.  At the time this was being collected Mike had said that Theresa and I would be cosigners in case something happened to the older members.  The reason we include our daughter is because of her age and the knowledge that she cares deeply about perpetuating this account so that it can be a source of income for

element_texts.text:
the long term benefit of the IWW.

  We certainly agree that we must do something to prevent the bank from ending up with this money.
  One additional thought is to combine this Book Fund with the Game fund if it is still available.  By the way can you refresh our memory about what has become of the Game fund.  Do you know what became of it, how it was handled.
  We'll be looking forward to hearing from you again and perhaps together we can resolve this issue.

Best Regards to you and Mary,
Sincerely,
Jamie and Patty.

Dear Mr and Mrs. Edwards:

 I received your card a couple of days ago, also your letter of about 10 days ago.  Did you receive the letter I wrote to you after I got home from Seattle?  The reason I am asking is - I am wondering if there is anything wrong with this mail service.
 I am sending you a receipt of a certified letter which I mailed to F. W. Thompson at the Buena postoffice, which is just a mile from our home.  Buena is about 16 miles east of Yakima.  The postmaster assured me that this letter would reach Chicago the following day and as the deadline for articles for the paper is from the 15th to the 20th this letter should have reached them in plenty of time to make the

My wife and I spent 2 hours writting [sic] up this article and made mention of each and every fellow Worker that was in attendance also told of your participation in the discussions and of the tremendous applause which you received.  Please send this receipt back to me by return mail as I will need it to put a tracer on the letter.  I checked at the postoffice and they told me the letter had definately [sic] gone out the same morning that it was mailed.  I can't understand what is taking place - something must be damned rotten in Denmark - It is very strange that both letters containing articles of the last two Labor History Conferences that we attended should both be lost before they ever reached Headquarters.  I sent this letter by Air Mail and also certified it on May 14.  Last year we wrote an 8 page letter.  They told me last year that the letter had got misplaced and

they found it 2 months later and by then it was too late to put it in the paper.  Now! whats going on this time?  I will need this reciept [sic] badly as all the f. w's will be asking about the Article that wasn't in the paper and this is the only proof that I have that I really did send one in.
I also mentioned (in the article) Mrs. Edwards many kindnesses shown us while we were guests in your home and I also told about the disorganization of the meeting and how poorly it was presented in comparison to the Conference held in Spokane last year.  It seems to me the Headquarters is interested in only "one stamp" card members - not those who pay their dues by the year and contribute to all their drives, as I and many others have done in the past.  Feel free to show this letter to anyone you wish to - even  to Chicago if you want to - as I will not write to them anymore, as I have had it!

I am seriously considering dropping the hammer and pulling the pin and that will be all she wrote - Dear John.

  Enclosed find a letter I received from Eugene Nelson who tells me they have put on a traveling delegation - a hitch-hiking traveling delegate - who has as much of a chance at sprouting wings and flying to the moon as he does have of being effective as a delegate as he can not possibly cover the back country where the real workers are.  He will only be able to hit the high spots and bigger branches while traveling in this manner.  So I guess in regards to Gene - his program has gone down the drain.  the only cooperation I have ever gotten from Chicago was from F.W's Keller and Westman.
  Well I could go on and on - but what the hell!

Hope this finds you both in good health.  Let me hear from you.
Yours for the O.B.U.   Fellow Worker X325505  Geoge Underwood  DEL. 71-5

I am sending you a receipt of a certified letter mailed to Just.   As you can see they received it on March 24th.  I requested a receipt so that I would know if they did receive it. Fred W. Thompson
Dear Fellow Worker,

  Herb has asked me to write to acknowledge your recent letters - including the one written from Richmond Virginia.  He has had a sharp attack of rheumatism with all its accompanying miseries and - much to his distress - he is unable to write or type himself.
  He has just reread your letter of Feb 20th and would like to comment on that more fully, but this will have to suffice at this time.
  At present he would like to know if you will remain at your home address after you return to Chicago.  That is, long enough for him to send a financial report to that address.  Having completely lost contact with the G.S.T., he does not feel he can risk sending any more financial statements there.  But neither does he want to be a delinquent        deligate {sic] - which

We had a very fine visit with Gene Nelson as he passed through Seattle on his way to Vancouver.  today we received a letter from him from California.  He surely seems to have the knack for getting along with people and we think he would be excellent material for a travelling organizer, not to mention another position where a change seems to be badly needed.
  We hope that you had a [crossed out: happy and] successful trip, and that you and Aina are in good health and humour! 

(For some reason best known to himself my dear Herb objects to the word "happy".  so that's why it's scratched out!  If ever I had to be a secretary I'd just hate to have him for a boss.  The maddening thing is I can't help liking the guy!)
Best wishes and regards.   Helen Edwards

3  Fred:  The changes you want to make at the top of page 9 - I suggest you insert them as it is a bit hard for me to follow you.
Page  10, last seven lines:  I was trying to introduce a Marxist view of wages here.  If Ken no longer wants to be Marxist - that is their business I guess.  Do as you wish. It is not my company.
p. 11-12.  I am unaware of any objection in ARU to taking in Pullman workers on the ground they they [sic] were not R.R. workers.  There might be some documentation for it but I have not seen any objection except in Grover Cleveland's speech of 1904 at Princeton.
page 14  I can't understand your asking me what official action the union took and when - as this information is in the 2d paragraph.  The transformation of boycott into a strike - mentioned in Paragraph 4, was not a national action - but the action of the various locals.  When a boycotter got fired - the local struck.  ARU  was decentralized.

element_texts.text:
21 Dec 81
Dear Fred:
Missed hearing from you but was plagued with medical problems in the family this year. Finally got back on MJ writing but here is the jolly golly season & John, Son #1, home last week for emergency appendectomy so the dust gathers again on typewriter.
I served as consulting historian to Terry Sanders who's working on Mother Jones docu-drama. He & his co-worker wife & their 2 girls & sitter were here for several days. Took Terry and Frieda up cabin & Point Creeks. There were shots in the hills above us which gave them quite a start. Actually it was wild turkey or squirrel season. I haven't seen the script yet but a pro is writing it. All now hangs on funding the film & Lord knows what will happen with that idiot & his fiscal policies running things from Washington.
Did you make the ILHS mtg in October? I really would have like to have heard a couple of the papers.
Had a postcard from Phillip Foner

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
He's teaching American labor history in China & says he telling the Mother Jones story to his students. Says his book Mother Jones Speaks to the Miners will be out in Spring, 1982 by International Publishers.
Ed Steel hitting some interesting stuff for his collection of MJ correspondence. I was interested in the military intelligence reports on MJ during Palmer's campaign & the steel strike.
Went to Morgantown & read Lillian Burgess mss.  Not much there but reports of MJ's visitors interesting.
Don't know what Ed's publishing plans are.
I've been working on proposal for publisher, outline & two chapters since October but I haven't the drive I had before surgery. Guess it takes longer when you get older - except for you.
Hope all is well with you & yours Have a Merry Christmas & Happy New Year
Best Regards 
Lois McL

element_texts.text:
To: Fred Thompson
From: Louis Carrick
Athens -- August 9, 1979
Dear Fred:
I have before me the last letter I received from you. It is dated April 12. I also have note of April 22. Can it be that four months have gone by without us exchanging letters? Well, I shall try to make up for this lapse in our correspondence. Your letters mean a great deal to me, Fred. I hope you will find time to answer this one of mine soon.
First, let me thank you for handling my membership effective May 1. I am now a paid-up member in the Public Service IU through December 31, 1979. It is my intention to keep paying my dues to the IWW and to write for the INDUSTRIAL WORKER -- until oxygen no longer gets up to my cerebral cortex. I hope when I turn in my tool checks, I shall die a member of the IWW in good standing. I shall continue to submit poems and articles for publications under my pen name Louis Burcar. When my name appears in the IW re articles or donations to the Sustaining Fund, it is better that it appear as the pseudonym by which I became known in the IWW movement than in the form of Louis B. Carrick, the "legal" name under which I now am enrolled in the red membership card I treasure as "Research Biologist," Card No. x 331947, and under which I write checks payable to the organization and also receive the IW and other mail from the General Executive Board. Fellow worker M. Hargis now has this double name business straightened out, I believe.
[ In left margin: ] Fred: Please send me by return mail Frank Cederwall's address and telephone number. We are going to ask him to be one of the principal speakers on September 30 at Barnwell ?  civil disobedience -- will pay his expenses to SC.

LC to FT
8/9/79
I am now working as a self exploiter as you will note from the enclosed CONSULTANT business card. (I resigned from the Federal service July 16, 1979.) I shall send one of these cards to Fellow Worker Hargis so he can transfer me from I.U. 670 to whatever Industrial Union consultants and writers in the field of human ecology may properly belong.
I gain from your note of April 22 that you didn't like my ballad "HARRISBURG BLUES." But the young scissorbills in the anti-nuke movement down here like it. Lin Mc Nickel Odend'hal, an Athen's folk singer, liked it so much she set it to music and sang it June 2 at a big demonstration at the State Capital steps in Atlanta. (See photos.) Frank Marquart also read the piece as the close of his speech on May Day in Albuquerque. He wrote me it went over big. Lin also got a big hand when she sang H B. We have copyrighted the words and music just so no big-shot could record the piece without clearing with Lin who owns the copyright. Mary scored the piece from LIn's cassette. I shall send you copy of the thing under separate cover. You can try the piece on your own piano -- even if you don't like illogical propaganda songs.
The condensation of my "INVOCATION FOR MAY DAY"you sent me in your April 12 letter shows excellent taste. You used the two stanzas that were most original and forceful. Now

LC to FT  3.
8/9/79
Mary is setting the "Invocation" to music. When she gets the music written, I'll send you a copy so you can try it out. I am submitting "Invocation for May Day" with music for publication in the IW May Day issue of 1980.
Now as to the sonnet you have on file "In Memory of Joe Hill (executed October 19, 1915). I am typing a clan copy and submitting it to the Editorial Collective for publication in a mourning box in the November issue of the IW.
By the way, Frank sent me a Joe Hill petition. Please let me know how the centennial affair is shaping up. I am completely isolated from the movement down here. I carry on as a speaker in the local anti-nuke movement. And, as I believe I showed in my article in the American Nuclear Society which appeared in the July issue of the IW, I am trying to hit with facts at the soft underbelly of the nuclear power industry. I liked the way my piece was featured. I had to call attention through FW Harris, however, that quotation marks in the printed article were improperly placed with relation to periods and commas.
I see from the last bulletin that the IW is in bad straits. I noted you kicked in a $100 for the fund. I shall also contribute when I get some consulting work. Will send you my brochure under separate cover with article which appeared setting forth my position on nuclear power and nuclear warheads in last Thursday's Athens-Banner Herald.
I am doing what I can -- and know you are probably doing more than one man should. Yours L

May 17, 1969     
Aissa and Fred Thompson
Dear Friends,
While you were here I promised to mail you a photocopy from the Joe Hill"s "Testament" music. Well finally I did get it done. But like I explained to you that the music that we have is only for mixchorus with finnish words so I'm not sure if this will be any good to you but will sent it anyway.
Hope that your trip back home went fine. We are also going back North soon although now we have it so nice here that a person hates to leave but as long as we still have our lake cabin in Minnesota we should go there to spent the summer but I do hope that it will be a little warmer than it was last summer.
We both wish you a nice summer.
Olga and Charles Hill

Letter to Tom McEnroe   Aug. 13, 1957
" . . . It seems to me that far more of the evils that we face have been fathered by good intentions than by people seeking to do harm or callous about consequences. Maybe what bites me is the large number of instances of the especially mean and malicious things that have been done all for high-sounding moral principles. My favorite text on ethics is Mark Twain's The  Mysterious Stranger."

element_texts.text:
224 Caselli Ave
San Francisco 14, Calif
May 11, 80
Dear Fred,
One of the last things I did before I left school was to address an envelope to you so that I could send you the Boose folktale reference. Here I am 2000 miles away and some months later with said envelope on my desk.
Here goes: B. A. BOTKIN, A Treasury of American Anecdotes, N.Y., Random house, 1957. Page 200-201 has Boose's tale, "The Non-Union Calf's Head." Page 301 in a note tells that Botkin collected it August 31, 1950 in Portland, Oregon.
You might enjoy reprinting it in the l. W.  I have already sent to Botkin  the I. W. stories on Boose's death in 1959. It would be interesting to get a letter or comment on the origin of the tale or any variants.
Now I'll give you a brief report on my activity since we last talked to each other.  From school I returned home for a brief visit in late January. On Feb 12 I returned to Chicago to help launch Glazer's book. I spent a month on the road lecturing on laborlore.  My trip took me from Chicago to Carbondale, Ill., Bloomington, Ind., Columbus, Ohio, Cornell and Rutgers universities, N.Y.C.  and Washington D.C. and home via Detroit for a visit to Solidarity House.

2
When I arrived back in San Francisco I was  broke so I returned to the trade. In this period I did no writing. Several weeks ago I took off to look for a library job. I may catch on at San Francisco State College which is close to home. So in the past two weeks I have been trying to write and study a bit. 
Joe Glazer sent me your review of his book. I enjoyed your comment on Casey Jones. In fact I've been doing a bit of reading and speculating as to how the error came about. I'll put all my ideas together into a little article on "the folksong as a historical document." In fact, John Greenway did such an article which I present to you with this letter because of your interest in the subject.
In my own reading on the Harriman Strike I have used 2 books in my library: Carl Person, The Lizard's Trail, Chicago, 1918, and vol 10 of the 1916 US Commission on Industrial Relations, Reports pages 9697-10066. Person deals chiefly with machinists on the Illinois Central. The U.S. Commission Report contains good testimony by John G. Taylor who was the I.A.M. rep. for the California machinists on the S.P.
But what I lack, Fred, is some account in print of the strike in San Pedro in the early months. I assume that the song

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
3
was written by Hill fairly early in the strike. I'd like to find a book, magazine, or press story on the strike in Pedro when Hill was there. In short, I want some peg upon which to hang his song. If you can help with a reference I may have overlooked please let me know.
By the way, do you know what happened to Person after he wrote the Lizards Tail?  In a sense, Person and Hill had similar reactions to the strike but the song lives on and the book is a forgotten item. I'd like to comment on the contrast.
Now I'll indicate why Glazer's error came about. This is my personal theory. All the people who write about Hill -- pro and con -- seem to be cast under a spell that forgets fact and compounds error.
Chaplin  in Wobbly, pg. 186 places the song on the great strike on the SP in 1910. He is wrong on name of strike and date. Stegner in Preacher and Slave, pps. 13-28 calls it a trainmen SP strike in June, 1910. He repeats Chaplin and involves an operating craft not actually on strike. Stavis in Man Who Never Died, pg. 3, corrects date to 1911 and calls it an SP strike. Note all 3 accept fact of strike but title it S.P.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
4
Now Greenway comes along in A. F. S. P., pg. 186, and says "company records and newspapers show no evidence of a strike" (SP, 1910). Of course  there is no evidence if you look for wrong name and wrong year. In reality, Greenway didn't look hard because Harry McClintock told John it was the Harriman Strike of 1911 which John printed, but didn't follow th to document. At least, McClintock's statement is finally on the record.
Along comes Glazer who combines Stavis and Greenway to make a blooper. There is a further serious error in Stavis when he asserts that Casey Jones was Hill's first known and first printed song. pg. 3. On pg. 8 he calls Preacher & Slave the second of Joe Hills songs. The reverse is true. P. & S. was introduced in Portland in fall of 1910 and printed in summer of 1911, and C J was composed in fall of 1911 and printed in little red songbook in summer of 1912.
I believe that Stavis's error in dating C J helps give it an early or 1910 feeling or at least helps place it before the strike started.
I'll be glad, Fred, to get your comments on my sequence and theory. Now I need some specific help. I'll want a comment on Lizard's Tail in?  Person.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
5
I'll want a reference to an SP strike story out of Pedro in late 1911 or early 1912.
But most important, have you ever seen the cards on which the song was first printed?  Neuhaus never had one.  I've never seen one reproduced.  I assume the back of the card would have had a message such as "support the strike and possibly a date. Or even a story in the Ind. Worker in late 1911 -- early 1912 that might have said, buy SP song cards. I have the I.W. on microfilm and when I get a chance I'll read these key issues cover to cover. But let me know where to get the original Casey Jones song card. 
There is a final question. Most early "biography" on Hill came from Chaplin. He wrote an early story for the Industrial Pioneer which he later rewrote for the New Masses. Do you have the dates of either of these stories?  I want to read them and compare to his Wobbly account in 1998.
Do you have any memory of anyone writing a "true" history of Hill's Casey Jones? It is devastating to do research and find that it's been done before.

In left margin, addition reads: Ind. Pioneer Nov 1923

24 Palms, Calif
Jan. 2, 1970
Dear f.w. F & A.
Your letter of Dec. 27--69 with ref. to the contents of the Joe Hill song book just issued. Yes sir "nearer my job to Thee" is on page 19 of the above mentioned song book the English version on the next page. The editor says that "it was published in the sixt edition of "The Little Red Songbook." The melody from Lowell Masons "Nearer My God to Thee." The editor name is Enn Kokk  "Coffee An" is on page 32 and titled "Räkna noga" in the Swedish version  It was translated by Jacob Branting and a good job I would say. Musik: E O Excell 1897 ("Count Your Blessings") "Räkna noga" means count carefully.  "Where the Fraser River Flows" which has appeared in some IWW version uncredited to J. H is on page 24. This one is definitely Joe Hillish and Frenchy Moreau, Lone Pine Calif. now dead, did say that Joe Hill certainly was present at the Fraser River job at the time of the strike there. "Down in the Old Dark Mill" and "The Old Toilers Message" are not in this song book and as you imply these may have been written by somebody else.
I don't have a copy of Joyce Kornbluh work on IWW songs. Had it loaned to me by John

Sept. 18, 1979
Chas. H. Kerr Publishing Company
600 W. Jackson Blvd,,
Chicago, Ill.
Attention Beret Rosen
Gentlemen:

  Some months ago I wrote to you requesting  the return of my manuscript and the $1000.00 given toward publication of same, to which I have received no reply.
  In view of the fact that neither you nor An Illinois Labor History see their way [?] to publish it, I want to make several dozen of mimeograph copies and hereby demand return of my manuscript and the $1000.00 given to Kerr & Co.
  Should you fail to answer this letter, I will be compelled to take legal action.

Yours [?signature: James S Abrams?]
To Beret Rosen:  I am asking for [?] to pick up my Zenith Television which you failed to repair or sell for me as you suggested.  [signature: ?James S Abrams?]

[letterhead]
NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY  COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES  Department of History  Evanston, Illinois 60201  Telephone: (312) 492-3406

29 April 85
Dear Frank Adams,

   I received your understandably angry letter last Friday but never got a copy of Thompson's letter to you.  He called me at one point saying he had some reservations about whether Kerr readers -- a notoriously hard-to-define group -- would like the sections on the New Deal and so much on Dombrowski's youth.  I said that I agreed cuts should be made but am very surprised that he wrote saying the book was rejected.   We have a board meeting on 11 May and I will see to it that the issue is resolved, hopefully favorably there by vote.
  Let me reiterate my position and expalin from my viewpoint what has happened to the manuscript.  It sat at Kerr for some months waiting for me to read it upon returning from abroad.  I read it and wrote you to say I liked it and thought it an appropriate Kerr book if there were money.  I also said you might be better advised to try elsewhere.  Your wrote back to say you'd "wait in line". for Kerr to publish.  I pointed out that without cuts and money for printing raised in advance by friends of the book we could not realistically agree to publish it,    ➞

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
at least not for many years.  I was not sure from your letters to me or to Franklin Rosemont whether you thought the money could be raised in advance or only with a tour after publication.  Nor was I sure how a publicity tour would be funded.  Therefore when the book came up at our last meeting and when Fred asked to see it for review I agreed hoping to get suggestions on cutting from the most laconic author I know.   I hoped he'd agreed with my recommendation of it as an appropriate Kerr book but, since we were not straight on financing, I could not press for a vote to publish.

   In the 11 May meeting I will ask for approval to publish pending cuts and raising of the printing costs.  (How much is cut will affect how much needs to be raised).  I think that the meeting should decide in favor given those conditions.  It is possible, if Fred feels strongly, that a third reader would look at it.  I doubt that will happen but if it does I will try to make Franklin Rosemont who liked the ms. based on a brief reading, responsible and get him to act quickly.
  I agree that the situation is a mess and am sorry for the inconvenience.

Sincerely   [signature]  Dave Roidyer

March 5, 1982
Francis Heisler  Rt 1 Box #25, Carmel Ca 93923
Mr. Carl [?Cowl?]  84 Ramson Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201

   Dear Carl [?], I read over your letter many times, because it gave me quite a problem about proceeding against the Publishing Company or against Rosen.  The latter I discarded promptly, since I agree with you that Rosen is totally irresponsible, as I learned from his not answering [?] of my letters.  That idea extended to the company too, and I am afraid that suing it, [?] and [?] will throw the company into bankruptcy and [?thus?] the last and only labor publishing enterprise will disappear.  Do you have any suggestion since I know that neither you nor I want that to happen.
  It seems to me the Rosen and the company live from  hand to mouth and the books on the shelf are there because they do not sell, thus if we get a judgment, it will be incollectable.  Could you contact [?] again, likely he has the answer, what I do not have.

Sincerely Francis Heisler

Francis Heisler  Rt 1 Box #2[?], Carmel, Ca, 93923
April 6, 1982
Dear Fred Thompson

  In your letter of March 20 of this year you tell us (to me and to Carl [?] that you are "shocked" by my letter of March 8 & [?]'s letter of the 17th  Let me tell you two things.  1. You did not read my subsequent letter to [?C. ?] in which I advised against a law suit for what I consider good reason, i.e. it would only hurt the Ker Co without helping [?]  2.  I am not only shocked but outraged, when I read that Fred Thompson of all people can be as cavalier to write "Sooner or later [?S?]'s money was used as collateral for the Amalgamated loan to finance the [?B?] book and that's where this is"
  All that I know about Fred Thompson that does not sound like him.  He I thought would disapprove such dishonesty and would not callously sow his neutrality (if that it is ) towards immorality, even though that word sounds quite bourgois.  that [?S..best?]'s book is sectarian and "thus in conflict with our publishing plan".  If that is so I would have expected the Kerr Co to tell that [?] to [?Son...?]; give back his money and withall his manuscript and not fool him and readers of Kerr publications that the [?Swa...?]'s book is in the work will be published

in 1978 or thereabouts.

  There is one more thing that you ought to know.  Before I was struck by bone cancer end of Oct 1980, I travelled regularly to my Chicago office.  I was invited to join the Kerr Board.  I told [?] & Rosen that I will do whatever I can for the Publishing Co, without taking a place away from some-one who is around Chicago - and available while I was away most of the time from there.  That however did not stop me from beginning to find a way to obtain financial help for Kerr.  I thought, as you do, that some of the books published ought to be read, - if not by the general public, then by trade-unionists.  I have some good contact with the top-people of well-fixed unions.   I called upon them suggesting that the International buys a few hundred well-chosen books and give them to the library of [?] [?].  Unfortunately - as you know, - there is never any money for educational purposes and thus I did not get any place, but I did not give up.
  I read your enthusiastic description of Rosen's contribution to the worthwhile Publication Co.  I do not take away anything from Rosen, to whom I wrote a number of times suggesting that Sarabeck right to be given his manuscript [?] and his money be returned to him as soon as possible.  Rosen never once answered me.  do you think that that is proper?

  As to your suggestions that I (or both [?] & I) find an "angel" who would finance the placing some (or all) of the Kerr books in the countries public libraries.  I was looking around high & low.  However I represented for 51 years, little people who may have been angels, but not with [?] so I was not successful there [?].  But I did not live up these [?], because I believe that the Kerr Company is badly needed together with a more effective Board and more effective manager than Rosen, who apparently rubs the people the wrong way.
  I hope that you did read the above to the effect that I believe that [?Arne Sorabed?] might be given his money and primarily his manuscript promptly so that he may find a publisher somewhere else.  That will not happen if Rosen learns that I am opposed to the lawsuit, therefore please keep that to yourself,

Wishing you well, I remain faithfully  Francis Heisler

148 Howland Ave., Toronto Ontario Canada  MSR 3BS 
2/8/78
Dear Fred.

   Many thanks for your letter of March 21th.  It was a very pleasant surprise to get such a long, informative and encouraging letter back from you.  It's nice to know you're not the only one digging!  I've started reading through the International Socialist Reviews for Kerr information and, as you say, that is the major source for basic information on books published.  I've also found one or two leads in the "Publishers' Dept." including the location of an early British stockholder in [?S...ford?] in 1903.  I never realized that Kerr did so much publishing as early as 1903 though a lot of the cloth covered socialist titles must be from Sam Sonnershein imprints.
  The "Social Science Series", by the way, was published by Sam Sonnershein and later, I believe by Union.  Sam Sonnershein was the original publisher but was taken over by George Allen & Unwin around the turn of the century.  I think Union then continued distributing the original Sam Sonnershein with the Union name on the spine, until the stocks were exhausted.  This, however, is largely guesswork though I do have an 1896 San Sonnershein (No. 91-

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
F. W. Galton, ed. "Workers in their industries:) which is the original Sam Sonnershein book but with George Allen & Unwin printed on the spine and a note inside saying "this book is now published by George Allen & Unwin."  Thus by the time Kerr started distributing them they were probably Allen & Unwin.  That was a repub series and I think the Kerr ed. stating that 1 in 5 were of "utmost value to socialist students" is an underestimate.  Perhaps they mean 1 in 5 is Marxist, or [?] socialist, and the rest is doubtful because written by [?], [?] free-thinkers eh?   One strange omission from the Kerr list is the [?]'s "The working class movement in America" (No. 23 in the Sam Sonnershein series)?

   One other thing - Scribners was the official San Sonnershein agent in the U.S. perhaps Kerr [?} with them before Union took them over?  I've also enclosed a Sam Sommershein list (of 1896) for "your envelope" in case you don't have one.
  I will try and get in touch with Allen & Unwin this summer as I'm going to England and I'll let you know if I find out anything.
  I'm very pleased you're publishing the Mary Mary Reader and I've ordered a few copies.  The Mary Mary pamphlet "[?] Talks" was widely read in Britain and seems to have been one of the first things workers interested in socialism were suggested to read - I hope the publication goes well and that it gets more people interested.

Another very influential book on British workers has been the "Ragged trousered philanthropists" by Robert Tressell.  I was pleased to see an ad for that in the ISR (August 1914) and that it was being distributed by Kerr (published by Stokes).  If you know of any information on that - whether it sold well and was popular with American workers etc. I would be very interested.

  One last straw in the wind!  I'm also interested in the Vanguard Press of New York, especially for the period 1926-'30. and the publishing activities (again especially the distribution of their books in the UK).  Do you know anything about them - perhaps even old Kerr exiles were involved?  I have a leaflet of 35 of their books distributed in the UK by the National Council of Labor colleges (NCLC or [?] League) but I'd like to know more about their activities as they were of some influence in getting all kinds of socialist books into the hands of workers in Britain.  I wrote to the present Vanguard Press in New York some time ago but have heard nothing from them as yet.  I expect they have nothing to do with the original Vanguard Press of 1926 (though they operate from the same address I think)  Any ideas?
  I will finish off now.  I will certainly let you know if I come up with anything in England and I'll also send you anything I can for your envelope.  In the fall I might even get down Chicago way, in which case I'd very

148 Howland Ave., Toronto Ontario Canada MSR 3B5
23rd February 1980.
Dear Fred Thompson,

   Just a brief line to enclose a little material about Kerr publications.  If you remember I wrote to  you a year or duo ago about Kerrs and said I would send along copies of things I found.  I haven't written before now as I haven't found much in England unfortunately but I thought I would send along this brief note anyway to let you know I haven't forgotten and that I am still digging!
 The main source for piecing together the importance of Kerrs in  Britain will, I believe, but the Central Labour College/National Council of

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
Labour Colleges (MCLC) archive in Scotland. Unfortunately, for me this has only been recently (last year) opened to researchers & I haven't been able to visit it as yet.   I know from other sources however that Kerrs were the main source of Marxist literature in the UK right into the 1920s.  The following comment by J. T. Walter Newbold in 1918 is typical: "the demand for Marxist literature is tremendous.  Huge consignments of Kerr's books are being brought in and cleared out within a few days of arrival" ( [?], v. 10 (9) p. 219 - Oct. 1918).

  I've enclosed copies of 2 letters between Kerrs & the Labour College in 1928-'9 which I found at Warwick University Library (their modern Records Centre) and also a couple of Labour College stock lists for the same period.  As you can see one stock list is all Kerrs while the other is ½ Kerrs.  The most popular books apart from Captal Vol. 1 seem to have been Ferre's "Positive school of criminology", Boudin's "The ideal

system...." and Dietzgen's "Positive Outcome" & Philosophical essays:.  Fred Casey referred to in one of the letters was one of the main proponents of "Dietzgenism" in England and wrote a couple of books on how Dietzgen, in his service of understanding, completed what Marx and Engels had started!  He was bitterly assailed by the C.P. (and particularly by T. A. Jackson in his "Dialectics") for his efforts, and the whole episode is a little strange complicated (or simplified!) by the C.P.'s attempt to 'capture' the NCLC.

  Also enclosed is a short article by Charles H. Kerr on his publishing house for Plebs (Plebs was the unofficial organ of the Labour College in England) and an article which I thought you might like on the American "Ruskin".  (The Plebs & the Central Labour College were set up in 1909-10 after a dispute with Ruskin College over the refusal of the Ruskin College authorities to allow Marxian economics, amongst other things, to be taught.  This was mirrored about

exactly in the Chicago "Ruskin".  I'm sure you will know all about this but perhaps you haven't seen this particular article on it.)

  So that's  about it for now.  One other thing about Plebs & the Labour College was that Mark Starr was one of it's [sic] main people in the early days and wrote a couple of its textbooks.  He must have come to the U.S. about 1924 and worked with ILGWU and become it's educational director.  If you know anything about that move and his later evolution I'd be interested to know.
  Also!  I mentioned Robert Tressell's "The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists" to you when I wrote before and you were enthusiastic about it as I knew you would be.  In connection with it there is an excellent book on the book! which has just come out in paperback in England.  It's by Fred Ball and is called "One of the Damned" (Lawrence & Whishart £ 3.25).  
 Fred, amongst other things managed to track down

  Finally if I didn't thank you for all the [?]information?] you sent me before on Kerrs let me do so now.  I hope I'll have some more information to send on before too long and I hope this little bit is of some interest.

[?Fondonally,?]
Bob Jones (R. JONES)
P.S.  Despite my main interest in Kerrs being with the UK I am interested in any aspect of Kerrs in the U.S. and I'm looking forward to the "Mary Mary Reader"

11th March, 1980
Dear Fred Thompson.

  Just a brief response to your letter of Feb. 28 which I have just received.  I am very pleased to hear Mark Starr is still active and would much appreciate you getting his address for me.   I'm also pleased to hear that you enjoyed reading Plebs League material in Canada.  It is superb propaganda material and was of course very influential in Britain but does your comment mean it was less influential in Canada and the U.S.?   I have seen no evidence of such influence but you would know of it far better than me.  Perhaps Plebs and the National Council of Labour Colleges (NCLC) had some influence on the

element_texts.text:
Labour Colleges set up in the 1920s in Canada?  Did you have a sub to Plebs or was someone (yourself!) distributing a bundle?

  Your suppositions about the Montana "Ruskin College" being transposed to Illinois are correct to the best of my knowledge.
  Fred Casey wrote two books based on Dietzgen (and a lot of articles):  (i) "Thinking: an introduction to its history and science" (London: The Labour Publishing Co.) (1st pub. 1922; 2nd edition 1927)   (ii)  "Method in thinking.  a series of popular lectures" (Manchester:  Tutors of the S.E. Lancashire Labour College, 1933).  Fred Casey and Dietzgen were the subject of much debate and controversy in the late  1920s & 1930s.  This culminated in T. A. Jackson's book "Dialectics" (1936) which devoted considerable space to an attack on "Caseyism" and "Neo-Dietzgenism Marxism""  I'm not that well up on this controversy but it must be dealt with in the light of C.P. attempts to discredit and/or capture all independent (of the CP) Marxist organizations.  T. A.

Jackson was a prominent CP'er.  The only recent short comment on Dietzgen I've come across is by Stuart McIntyre in The Bulletin of the Society for the study of Labor History, No. 29 (1974) pp50-'4 and called "Joseph Dietzgen and British working class education."   McIntyre, however, is a CPer and thus his interpretations have certain inherent limitations.

   A good illustration of the importance of Dietzgen to both the British working class education movement (Plebs & the NCLC) and Kerrs is the fact that WW Craik (principal of the Labour College (London)) put out a new translation of "The positive outcome...." in 1928.  This was to celebrate Dietzgen's centenary and was published by Kerr.  It presumably superceded the old translation by Ernest Untermann (of 1906) published in Kerr's "International History of Social Science".  According to Kerr's ad. on the new translation it was "immensely superior.  It is in clear and expressive English, which simplifies the study."   This was badly needed

element_texts.text:
as students had a pretty tough time getting through Dietzgen.  The immense interest in Dietzgen in Britain is still a bit of a puzzle to me.  The fact that Dietzgen was a worker and had independently arrived at a dialectical materialist position may have been a strong initial attraction to a working class struggling to find a class philosophy of its own.  But that, I'm sure, is only part of the story.

  I'm glad the Kerr material will be of some use and I hope you had a good conference in Spokane.

Yours fraternally, Bob Jones

Dear Fred Thompson,
I am writing to see if you can help me in some research I'm doing which involves the publishing activities of Charles H. Kerr Books. I recently read your very interesting and stimulating memories of Halifax in 1919 in This Magazine and noticed in the comment by John Bell that like so many you learned your socialism from Charles H. Kerr books and that you are new on the board of that great publishing house.
I've been meaning to write to Kerr Publishing for some time now and after reading your article I thought you would be an excellent person

element_texts.text:
to address my enquiries to.
I'm engaged in research on the development of class consciousness among workers in Britain at the beginning of the 20th C. In Britain too, as you well know, many workers learned their socialism from Kerr books. I was wondering if there is a complete listing of Kerr books and pamphlets and if the company still has any records of printing runs of the works they published? -- and in particular any records on which books were distributed in Britain and how many copies they sold.
Also is there a list of the subscribers to the Kerr [?Coop.? ] from Britain? I have a copy of the 1913 Kerr edition of Arthur Lewis' "An introduction to Sociology" and at the back of that is "list of advance subscribers" but they all seem to be U. S. subscribers. Is there also a list of UK subscribers surviving somewhere?
I'm also obviously interested in the general

6 Lilian ST, Bradford, BD4 9LP England. 15/Jan. '81.
Dear Fred,
Many thanks for the letter you sent way back in March. Since then I've moved back from Toronto to England for a while and I thought I would wait until finding some more Kerr information before writing again.
As you can see for from the enclosed copy I've come across a Kerr share certificate which I hope is of some interest. It was held by Harry Brownjohn and is now in the possession of Eddie Crow who, I think, knew Harry well.  Harry (like Eddie) was an engineering worker & member of the SDF and ILP becoming a foundation member of the CP. He was also, not surprisingly, a member of the Plebs League and a class tutor.

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=5, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS 5DS R, software=Adobe Photoshop 22.0 (Windows), datetime=2020:11:1

element_texts.text:
One other vivid memory Eddie has is visiting one George (?) Sumpres of Leeds who had a room absolutely full of Kerr books for sale.
It is surprising that Kerrs (and other American material especially Vanguard Press & SLP pamphlets) were so important here and it would be very interesting to speculate why this was so. I suppose the simple reason was that there was no major socialist publishing co. here publishing anything on any sizeable scale.   Most socialist literature published here was put out by strictly commercial companies although a number were sympathetic, to some degree, to the labor movement.  I'm thinking here of Sam Sonenschein, T. Fisher Unwin & Co. Allen & Unwin in particular. The socialist publishing houses that did sell material on a large scale i.e.. the Clarion Press, Fabian Society/Grant Richards and the ILP Publication Dept supplied little or

element_texts.text:
2.
no Marxist material.  Only the SPF (Twentieth Century Press), the SLP (largely U.S. SLP material) and other smaller group supplied this but not on any large scale.   Thus by the second decade of the 20th C when a real interest in Marxist material was developing again, in part stimulated by Plebs classes, there was a large demand which only Kerrs could really meet.  Dietzgen's works are only one of many examples.  There was a great deal of interest in the work of Louis Boudin & his work "The theoretical system of Karl Marx" was thought of very highly, & justifiedly so I would think.  New Kerr titles were much discussed & debated especially the economic ones.  One interesting example that comes to mind is the reception give to Cahn's "The collapse of capitalism".  John Maclean in particular criticised

  Other little bits of information I've come across are that Allen & Unwin prevented the sale in England of the Kerr edition of Volume 1 of Capital in the early 1930's.  The relation between Kerrs & Allen & Unwin/Swan Sonnenschein would be very interesting to look into but I haven't been able to get access to their records.
  Also, I don't know if I've mentioned this before, but in a copy of Arthur M. Leavis' "An introduction to sociology" (Kerr, 1913 printing) I have, there is a "list of advance subscribers" at the back.  This is 8½  pp. of names - approx 1,000 who

element_texts.text:
Feb. 1980
To whom it may concern --
On May 1st, 1986, it will be 100 years since the "Haymarket Massacre" in Chicago, when the budding labor movement was struggling to make the 8-hr. day standard throughout the nation. One of their songs went,
"Eight hours we'd have for sleeping
Eight hours we'd have for play
Eight hours we'd have for working
In Free Americay"
May 1st became an international labor holiday, but in recent decades, especially in the USA, each left-wing sect has held its separate observance, more of a memorial than a celebration, and established unions tended to ignore the date completely, or join the "Loyalty Parades" sponsored by the American Legion.
I think that musicians and song-leaders are needed now to take the initiative, and project a little unity into the situation. One week (or one month?) before Mayday, in each city and town of the country, we should invite one and all to an evening which could be advertised as "A  May Day Centennial Rehearsal Warm-up." A number of different singers and song leaders could be invited, and a few basic rules agreed upon: 
1. No speeches, except a 30-second introduction

element_texts.text:
p.2
to a song, briefly establishing the singer's point of view, or organizational base.
2. A balance between new and old songs. A pure historical survey, with all songs in chronological order, might get pretty boring. So each singer might search for contrasts, and agree to sing at least one old and one newer song.
3. Face up to disagreements, and sing songs that don't always agree with each other. This will add a good dramatic tension to the evening, and even some humor.
4. A printed songbook should be available so everyone present could go back (to their local union?) and lead a few songs somewhere on May 1st
Who knows, if such programs are put on for six years in a row, perhaps in 1986 there might even be some united celebrations of May Day.
In 1980, our songfests will be pitifully small because of lack of time and money for preparation, but I mail these pages to friends in many places, hoping for letters in response. Here I jot down, off the cuff, names of singers and songs I'd try to get for such a gathering, if I

   Who else would you choose? I am weak on names from the south and west.  Of course in a two hour program you can only get about 30 songs and if each singer only did two songs, you'd have time for only 15 singers.  If necessary, two or three song leaders could carry the evening.  But ideally you'd have more:  women and men; young and old; black, white, native american; chicano and other hispanic and ethnic backgrounds, with many accents and different musical idioms.
 Songs I suggest here are in chronological order though probably it would be better to bob and weave, and end the program with an old one (Solidarity?) along with a newer one (If I had a hammer?).  (or "This Land is Your Land"?)

element_texts.text:
p. 5

   As I finished this list I realized I'd skipped large areas:  farmer's songs. songs of the dust bowl, pacifist and anarchist songs, songs of the grape-boycott, the Black Panthers, satires of many sorts, from Pins & Needles (1930's) to Tom Paxton's song about Anita Bryant.
   Needless to say, yer can't sing 'em all, not in a month of Sundays.  And it would be foolish to attempt to foist an inferior piece of music on the audience.  But now I get to the end of my memo and repeat:
  1.  Would you let me know what you think of the idea?  ;How would you develope [sic] it?
  2.  What other singer would you invite to participate?
  3.  What other songs would you include?
  4.  How would you publicize it & fill the hall?

I'd suggest trying to reach regular "conservative" union members first, then reach out to as many different "radical" groups as possible, including ones that profess to dislike each other.
Let me hear from you
Pete
[drawing of banjo}

element_texts.text: memory Loss. and Laziness.  So much has happened with the Wobblies since I came:  Frances Thorpe came over and said "I'm a Jew" and I said and I'm a Finn & what shall we do about it?"  She confided to me that she suffered Nite Mares and her husband, Frank saved her life when she tried to jump from a window.  Shortly later a Finn was transported from San Francisco to Helsinki.  I think he was a communist.  Frances called me & asked what the Finns were doing about it.  I didn't think they were doing Anything.  Shortly after Frank, her husband, called and told me Frances had jumped to her death from their Bathroom window.
